quotes.topic_title: JTBD rant teaser: Facebook onboarding example
quotes.text: I hate Jobs-to-be-Done, I think it is a terrible framework, I think no successful company has ever been built on top of JTBD and if you pick JTBD, you're probably doomed and I'll give you an example.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A contrarian critique that challenges a popular product framework and sets up a concrete example to reconsider how teams use JTBD.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD rant teaser: Facebook onboarding example
quotes.text: Facebook knew that it needed to get you to 10 friends in 14 days. If you got your 10 friends in 14 days, you were probably going to use Facebook.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A specific activation metric example practitioners can use as a model for defining leading indicators of retention.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD rant teaser: Facebook onboarding example
quotes.text: So it'd be like, "Well, we're going to throw every tool we have at our disposal to get you to 10 friends and 14 days."
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Illustrates an aggressive onboarding/activation optimization mindset tied to a clear behavioral threshold.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD rant teaser: Facebook onboarding example
quotes.text: So what Facebook did was it made your experience slightly worse to make that person's experience slightly better.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of cross-user tradeoffs in networked products where one user’s growth can degrade another’s experience.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD rant teaser: Facebook onboarding example
quotes.text: This was performing no job for you, it was trying to perform a job for them.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A sharp critique of JTBD framing in multi-sided/network contexts, where the “job” may belong to a different user than the one experiencing the feature.

quotes.text: Together they host the Aarthi and Sriram Good Time Show, which started on Clubhouse, it's now on YouTube and famously they had Elon Musk on back in the day, which led to Clubhouse's crazy rocket ship growth, which we definitely touch on.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of how a single high-profile guest appearance can catalyze massive platform growth and distribution.

quotes.text: We cover all kinds of areas, including this trend of techno optimism, building your network, creating content online and how to go about doing that, becoming a product leader, community building and a hilarious rant at the end about why the Jobs-to-be-Done framework does not work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews several practitioner-relevant themes, including a contrarian critique of a popular product framework (Jobs-to-be-Done).

quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that security compliance is a gating factor for enterprise sales and can directly impact revenue momentum.

quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights SOC 2 as a gating factor that can directly accelerate or stall go-to-market progress, especially with larger customers.

quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table beginning.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that compliance can be a prerequisite for enterprise conversations, not a later-stage nice-to-have.

quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point that can help teams benchmark automation potential for compliance work.

quotes.text: Dovetail allows you to quickly analyze customer data from any source and transform it into evidence-based insights that your whole team can access.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Encapsulates an actionable workflow: centralize multi-source customer data and convert it into shareable, evidence-backed insights.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting the duo and Good Time Show
quotes.text: And then the next day, Elon came on and then it just blew up and I was like, "Shit, I missed my chance."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A vivid example of how quickly opportunities can compound after a breakout moment—and how hesitation can create real opportunity cost.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting the duo and Good Time Show
quotes.text: And so I look back at that as like, "Oh, I hesitated too long. That's a lesson."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A direct takeaway practitioners can apply: move faster on scary-but-promising opportunities to avoid regret and missed upside.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting the duo and Good Time Show
quotes.text: A lot of people remember us for the Elon episode, but I will tell you this, it is often the folks who were working technology, who were not as famous, you're obviously very famous now, but who really connected with the audience.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive audience insight: less-famous, more “in-the-trenches” guests can resonate more deeply than headline celebrities.

quotes.topic_title: How Elon Musk came on Clubhouse
quotes.text: Well, I think it's actually similar to how a lot of good things in my career have happened, which is I just had a conversation on the internet.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A repeatable career-growth model: initiate public/online conversations to create unexpected opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: How Elon Musk came on Clubhouse
quotes.text: I have this whole thing where I do think a lot of people trying to get ahead in their career, especially in technology, should just write cold emails, cold DMs, notes, put out content, et cetera and that leads to good things.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice for practitioners on using outbound outreach and content to accelerate career momentum.

quotes.topic_title: How Elon Musk came on Clubhouse
quotes.text: The crazy part of that story was I had texted him saying, "You should come on the show," and he said, "Sure," and then he tweeted about it.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A concrete example of how a simple ask plus amplification from a high-reach account can instantly change outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: How Elon Musk came on Clubhouse
quotes.text: And I will tell you that when Elon tweets about you and well, even maybe more so now, your phone just melts.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A vivid illustration of the operational impact of virality—be prepared for sudden, massive inbound attention.

quotes.topic_title: How Elon Musk came on Clubhouse
quotes.text: And we are like, "No, we're not. What gave it away?"
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: A contrarian stance on creator expectations: you don’t need to be a “professional journalist” to host meaningful conversations.

quotes.text: Once you've done this a few times, you kind of see everything as a funnel and you're like, "Well, are you retaining people? Are you not? Is it top of the funnel impressions or do they stick around?"
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: A practical growth lens: acquisition tactics only matter if they translate into retention and sustained engagement.

quotes.text: I will say, Clubhouse, I feel like they get this unfair attention and criticism. It's a what, three-year-old startup?
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to calibrate expectations for early-stage companies and avoid over-indexing on hype-cycle narratives.

quotes.text: So I mean, I feel like founders just need some time to breathe in and figure out what to go do.
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: Actionable leadership advice: allow iteration time before declaring product-market fit failure or success.

quotes.text: But one of the key takeaways from that piece is the idea that when you have a new network, think of it as a new country, you want the high status people and high status mean they're interesting, people want to be where they are in some shape or form because they have money, they're smart, they're cool, they're good-looking, whatever it may be and you want to get them onto your network.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for bootstrapping social networks: seed with “high-status” users to create gravitational pull.

quotes.text: And there's exactly an interesting corollary that they're often underserved by other existing platforms. And because if they're already well-served, they wouldn't want to move to you.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive acquisition strategy: target segments that incumbents underserve, especially among high-status users who can catalyze migration.

quotes.topic_title: Status, stars, and bootstrapping social networks
quotes.text: But one of the key takeaways from that piece is the idea that when you have a new network, think of it as a new country, you want the high status people and high status mean they're interesting, people want to be where they are in some shape or form because they have money, they're smart, they're cool, they're good-looking, whatever it may be and you want to get them onto your network.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for bootstrapping a new social network by treating it like a new “country” that must attract high-status early citizens.

quotes.topic_title: Status, stars, and bootstrapping social networks
quotes.text: And there's exactly an interesting corollary that they're often underserved by other existing platforms. And because if they're already well-served, they wouldn't want to move to you.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive acquisition principle: the best high-status targets are those with unmet needs on incumbent platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Status, stars, and bootstrapping social networks
quotes.text: One of the things you'll see is a lot of the folks from the Instagram world rarely move to TikTok and there's a couple of reasons. One, they didn't really need to because they were already popular on some of these other existing platforms, but two, TikTok actually took advantage of a different set of skillsets. People who are really good on video, people who could dance, be funny.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Explains why creator migration is hard and how new platforms win by rewarding different skills than incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Status, stars, and bootstrapping social networks
quotes.text: So every single time, I think you need to go after a set of people who are high status who are also underserved.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A concise, actionable rule for seeding networks: target users who are both desirable and dissatisfied elsewhere.

quotes.topic_title: Status, stars, and bootstrapping social networks
quotes.text: And so those are the people you pull in, the people not doing well on another platform that want to do well versus the people already killing it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical recruiting heuristic for new platforms: focus on “upwardly mobile” creators rather than entrenched winners.

quotes.text: So technology and computers have given us everything.
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: A concise, memorable thesis for techno-optimism grounded in lived experience rather than abstract ideology.

quotes.text: I think there's generally two schools of thought. One school of thought, I would broadly write up as things are getting worse, technology is making things worse and we should all do less, build less. And then the other school of thought, which I think I subscribe to, is technology is not perfect, the impact technology is definitely uneven, but pretty much most of the good things in the world over the last 100, 200 years are responsible for it.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A clear two-school mental model that practitioners can use to locate their own stance and debate tech’s net impact.

quotes.text: And I imagine like, "Hey, if he was born 40 years later and he had a laptop and an internet connection and could get on GitHub, here are opportunities that would be just impossible, even 30, 40 years ago and that's all from technology."
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A concrete counterfactual example showing how access to modern tools (laptop, internet, GitHub) expands opportunity.

quotes.text: I suspect the phone that you and I have is probably the same phone that... actually I know it's the same phone that Elon Musk uses, the richest person in the world.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A vivid, counterintuitive illustration of how consumer tech compresses status differences in access to core tools.

quotes.text: You go to google.com, google.com doesn't know your net worth, it gives you the same results. Chat GPT doesn't know how rich you are.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A practical observation about how key internet services can function as equalizers by defaulting to the same experience for everyone.

quotes.topic_title: Building a network and personal brand
quotes.text: But I've come to realize that that is just not true and this might be a controversial opinion, but you have to get out there and build your own brand.
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional “just ship and you’ll be recognized” career advice, especially inside large companies.

quotes.topic_title: Building a network and personal brand
quotes.text: So building a network is very simply having relationships with human beings. And let's start off by saying first of all, these have to be authentic, genuine relationships.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Reframes networking as genuine relationship-building rather than transactional ladder-climbing.

quotes.topic_title: Building a network and personal brand
quotes.text: Well, let's start off with go and meet every single peer that you have you don't directly meet with. Go get coffee with them and ask them, 'Hey.' Have no agenda. Just ask them what's going on in their life, who are they, what their life story is and then who are a couple of interesting people that you should meet with?
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable coffee-chat playbook (no agenda + personal curiosity + referral question).

quotes.topic_title: Building a network and personal brand
quotes.text: You do this, you do two coffees a week and literally just ask me two hours a week, everyone has two hours a week, it'll start compounding over overtime and time.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Provides a simple cadence and a compounding mental model for building a network over time.

quotes.topic_title: Building a network and personal brand
quotes.text: And what happens when you put yourself out there? It's a Bat-Signal. It's telling people that, "Hey, I'm here, this is my body of work," and you know what the internet does? It'll send amazing people to you.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Offers a memorable model for publishing work as a way to attract opportunities and high-quality connections.

quotes.text: By now, we've known each other for 20-ish years and this is every dinner, every event, this is just how he's wired and so you just can't fake that in building out a network. He builds a network by just wanting to know who these people are.
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: Highlights a durable networking principle: authentic curiosity is a compounding advantage you can’t manufacture with tactics.

quotes.text: But what I realized is a lot of folks sometimes just want to be with other amazing peers. And one sort of hack I built over the years, I was like, "All right, let me just bring interesting people together."
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable networking methodology: create value by convening high-quality peers rather than trying to impress them.

quotes.text: And I say, "Okay. You trust me, you trust me and I make the rules." Everyone keeps some level of confidence, everyone is a peer, they're all accomplished in their own way, no one is rude or mean or goes off the rails. So I'm a party host, so I'm like, "Okay listen, nobody is going to get super crazy over here," but I'm also curating.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Defines the “party host” model for micro-communities: explicit rules + confidentiality + active curation to maintain trust and quality.

quotes.text: You put together the group of people and they hang out online and over times, you have a very famous CEO becoming best friends with somebody in their early 20s who's just getting started just because they're in the same space together.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Concrete example of engineered serendipity: small trusted groups can collapse status barriers and create unlikely relationships.

quotes.text: But yours has hundreds of thousands of people and I think sometimes there's an intimacy from having smaller groups, like 5 people, 10 people like a shared space and then kick it off.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Counterintuitive community-building takeaway: smaller groups can create more intimacy than massive communities, even if the latter are successful.

quotes.topic_title: How to start communities: niche, vibe, rituals
quotes.text: You're almost better off doing these small, niche, non-scalable things to go find these oddball set of people who are doing this, who are really interested in this one thing and kind of scale from there and grow from there.
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice to start with deliberately unscalable, niche tactics to find true enthusiasts before attempting growth.

quotes.topic_title: How to start communities: niche, vibe, rituals
quotes.text: Two, I think people, and this might be a controversial thing, but I often think people don't think through monetization. If you're a community builder early on, start thinking about, if you're truly focused on this as a business, how would you actually make money off of it?
quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.context: Practical reminder that community builders should design monetization early to avoid painful retrofits later.

quotes.topic_title: How to start communities: niche, vibe, rituals
quotes.text: And I like to think of things like a dinner party or church or things that seem more tangible and people know, "Okay, I know exactly what that is." So when I think of a community or starting one, I think first of all, it's a party. And you're first starting off, you're like, "All right, what is a vibe?"
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that makes “community” concrete: treat it like hosting a party and explicitly define the vibe.

quotes.topic_title: How to start communities: niche, vibe, rituals
quotes.text: And if you don't do that, people make up their own rules. That's number one.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Actionable warning that failing to set norms/tone early leads to emergent (often undesirable) behavior standards.

quotes.topic_title: How to start communities: niche, vibe, rituals
quotes.text: The third part I love is rituals and religions do a great job of this, which is do something every month.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable mechanism for building trust and stickiness: recurring rituals on a predictable cadence.

quotes.text: Getting enough electrolytes helps prevent and eliminate headaches, muscle cramps, fatigue, sleeplessness and other common symptoms of electrolyte deficiency.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable health takeaway linking electrolyte intake to specific symptoms practitioners can watch for and address.

quotes.text: LMNT is the exclusive hydration partner to Team USA Weightlifting and many other Olympic athletes, also dozens of NBA and NFL teams and players rely on LMNT to stay hydrated, along with Navy SEAL teams, FBI sniper teams and the Marines.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete social-proof examples showing broad adoption across elite sports and tactical teams.

quotes.text: You can try LMNT totally risk-free. If you don't like it, you can share it with a salty friend and they'll give you your money back, no questions asked.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable risk-reversal policy that’s a reusable tactic for reducing purchase friction in product marketing.

quotes.text: I think a lot of times people hear that, like a first-year PM and they're like, "Yes, I'm going to start tweeting." And then it's such cringey useless stuff and nobody needs to hear from them because they haven't done anything.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Contrarian caution against premature personal-brand content before having real experience or unique insights.

quotes.text: Everyone should tweet or everyone should post on YouTube or post Instagram and it doesn't matter how young you are.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Contrarian stance that early-career people shouldn’t wait for seniority or “credentials” before publishing.

quotes.text: one is that you need to have hit a certain bar of accomplishment or interestingness to say something, strongly disagree with that.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that you must achieve big wins before your content is worth sharing.

quotes.text: Number one is what the most important thing and even, listen, if you just remember one thing from this whole thing is just get started and do something every single day.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Actionable habit prescription: daily output as the core driver of progress in content creation.

quotes.text: And with creating content, diet and exercise, you just write a piece of content every single day because what's going to happen is it builds muscle, it gets you familiar with the medium and you start understanding what works in that medium and what doesn't and you start building reps.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Memorable framework (“diet and exercise”) that emphasizes reps, medium fluency, and feedback loops over perfection.

quotes.text: The second part of it is, I actually think you don't have to talk about what you accomplish, you only have to talk about you.
quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.context: Practical content strategy for juniors: share your journey and learning rather than waiting for major achievements.
